important_phrase: Areas affected by drought conditions expanded in the District since the last report
Bankers indicated that lending activity continued to modestly improve
Firms that were experiencing difficulties filling vacancies, noted ramping up internal training programs to better position themselves to take on inexperienced workers
Bankers in Louisiana continued to report a slowdown in lending tied to the energy sector
Year-to-date total rail traffic was flat to slightly down, but intermodal volumes continued to grow; coal and iron and steel scrap shipments declined substantially compared with year-earlier levels
The majority of contacts reported that home sales increased from the year-earlier level, and that inventory levels remained the same or fell
Year-to-date Mississippi casino gaming revenues increased compared with the same period last year
Most software and information technology services firms are also seeing revenue growth, while increases at staffing firms are even more robust
Some contacts express concerns about the Chinese economy, the strong dollar, and stock market fluctuations
Despite strong demand, most respondents report little or no net hiring
Contacts say low inventory has created a strong "sellers' market
Inventories are slightly higher as a result of these slower-than-expected sales, but not a cause for concern
Egg prices increased again
Credit conditions were little changed
Non-wage costs declined slightly as fewer contacts reported pressures from benefits
Consumer credit demand increased slightly, with an uptick in applications from lower quality applicants
Hiring and hiring plans also grew at a moderate pace
Construction and real estate activity increased modestly over the reporting period
Relatively low gas prices continued to cause a shift in consumer preferences toward light trucks
Because of weak exploration activity, hiring within the oil and gas industry is modest and tightly controlled
Payrolls expanded slightly
Payrolls increased, on net
Reports indicated a slight expansion in payrolls
The average sales price increased by almost 6 percent
Stre traffic continued to decline, while on-line shopping expanded
Grain prices moved lower over the reporting period and farmers were managing costs in light of lower expected revenues
Price pressures remained subdued and employment held steady or increased
Airlines noted increased headcounts from a year ago and restaurants said hiring increased, although they reported difficulty finding suitable workers to fill openings in new restaurants
Loan standards were unchanged, and loan quality improved slightly
Demand for professional and technical services increased modestly over the reporting period
Commercial real estate activity generally held steady, and outlooks remained cautiously optimistic
Contacts said they expect little to no sales growth for the third quarter, with mixed levels of optimism
After rebounding briefly in June, crop prices declined sharply in July and early August due to improved growing conditions and expectations of a strong fall harvest
Manufacturing activity continued to decline primarily due to weakness in food, beverage, plastics, and metal production, but expectations remained modestly positive
Restaurant menu prices rose modestly
Deposit levels increased slightly, with respondents primarily split between reporting increased or steady deposit levels
Expectations for future activity remained modestly positive, but manufacturers' spending plans decreased markedly
Expectations for residential real estate activity remained positive, but many respondents expected slower growth over the coming months due to normal seasonal factors
Retail sales increased moderately from the previous survey period and remained higher than year-ago levels
Conditions improved for most District agricultural producers since the previous report
Agricultural conditions mostly improved
Prices remained relatively flat
Service-providing industries grew since the last report
Commercial real estate activity increased
Consumer spending was relatively level
Cattle prices increased in the Minneapolis and Dallas Districts, and decreased in Chicago
Most Districts reported modest to moderate growth in labor demand, although Boston, Cleveland, and Dallas cited only slight increases in hiring
Wges were relatively stable in most Districts, with slight to moderate increases since the last report
Credit conditions remained stable or improved across Districts
Demand for nonfinancial services generally expanded at a modest to moderate rate since the last report
Similarly, Boston noted difficulty in obtaining new construction permits
Boston and Atlanta reported mixed results--both Districts had some sources reporting that sales growth was improved or still strong, but other retailers reporting flat or slowing sales
Both commercial and multi-family residential construction remain fairly robust
Small- to medium-sized banks in the District report increased demand across all loan categories, with the most widespread gains for commercial and residential mortgages
Service-sector firms broadly report that business has continued to improve moderately in recent weeks, and they remain generally optimistic about the near-term outlook
Residential rental markets have been steady to somewhat stronger
Used vehicle sales were characterized as steady to increasing moderately
Manufacturing appears to have slowed somewhat to a slight pace of growth
Other contacts report some difficulties filling highly technical positions
Banking contacts in most parts of the District described a steadily growing economy with little sign of inflation
A few firms cited difficulties related to the strong dollar
Wile Philadelphia's Class A office space continued to command strong premiums, rents for most categories increased only slightly
Retail sales continued at a moderate pace
Natural gas prices remained unchanged since last report, and coal prices declined slightly
Prices of raw materials rose at a slower pace, while finished goods prices accelerated slightly
Manufacturing wages increased moderately and the average workweek lengthened
Credit standards were largely unchanged, although some tightening was reported in Wst Virginia
Manufacturing activity increased moderately since our last report
Commercial real estate activity increased moderately since the previous report
Sales of building supplies increased, and auto dealers reported flat to higher sales
Agricultural activity grew slightly over the reporting period
Manufacturing output grew modestly
Prices for agricultural products generally increased, with reduced acreage and yields creating modest supply shortages for some products
Lending activity grew modestly over the reporting period
Output in the manufacturing sector grew modestly
Real estate activity expanded at a moderate pace overall but was uneven throughout the District
Clothing and apparel sales expanded moderately after accounting for the normal back-to-school shopping boost
Conditions deteriorated slightly for corn and soybeans but improved for cotton and rice
Reports from manufacturers were mixed
A survey of about 150 District businesses indicated that wage growth in the District was moderate, while employment and prices grew modestly
Creditworthiness of applicants remained unchanged to slightly better in most loan categories
Expectations for new orders in the next quarter were similarly mixed
Residential real estate activity continued to expand at a steady pace
